thread.title: Marlon James wins Man Booker prize
thread.title_full: Marlon James wins Man Booker prize

title: Marlon James wins Man Booker prize
text:
'A Brief History of Seven Killings' (Photo: .)
CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Marlon James became the first Jamaican author to win Britain's prestigious Man Booker prize, for A Brief History of Seven Killings .
The winner was announced at a black tie ceremony in London on Tuesday.
"i was so convinced I wasn't going to win I didn't write a speech," James said. His novel is about the attempted assassination of Jamaican reggae artist Bob Marley in the late 1970s.
James received his award from Camilla Duchess of Cornwall, wife of Prince Charles. He gets 50,000 pounds.
Britain's Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, (R) speaks with Jamaican author Marlon James in London Tuesday. He won the Man Booker prize. (Photo: NEIL HALL, AFP/Getty Images)
This is the second year the literary prize was open to writers of any nationality, as long as the book is written in English and published in the UK.
The five other finalists were:
A Spool of Blue Thread by Anne Tyler (United States)
Satin Island by Tom McCarthy (UK)
The Fishermen by Chigozie Obioma (Nigeria)
The Year of the Runaways by Sunjeev Sahota (UK)
A Little Life by Hanya Yanagihara (U.S.)
